Title: Sets containing all their proper subsets
Content: I know that $\emptyset$ and $\{\emptyset\}$ contain all their proper subsets. I am trying to show that no other set satisfies this property, i.e. there is no set $x$ such that $\forall y \subsetneq x (y \in x)$ . Is this true? If so, how can I prove this?

Okay, so I need to figure out if there are any sets besides the empty set and the set containing the empty set that contain all their proper subsets. The user is asking if those two are the only ones, and if so, how to prove it.

First, let's recall what a proper subset is. A proper subset of a set X is a subset that is not equal to X itself. So, if a set X contains all its proper subsets, every time you take a subset Y that's not X, Y has to be an element of X.

We know that the empty set ∅ trivially satisfies this because it has no proper subsets. Similarly, {∅} has only one proper subset, which is ∅, and ∅ is indeed an element of {∅}. So those two work.

Now, the question is: are there any other sets with this property? Let's suppose there is a set X that is not ∅ or {∅} such that all its proper subsets are elements of X.

Let's consider a simple case first. Take a set with one element, say X = {a}. Its proper subsets are just ∅, so X must contain ∅. But X is {a}, so unless a = ∅, this isn't true. If a = ∅, then X = {∅}, which we already know works. So singleton sets other than {∅} don't work.

Next, consider a two-element set, say X = {a, b}. Its proper subsets are ∅, {a}, and {b}. Therefore, X must contain ∅, a, and b as elements. Wait, but X is {a, b}, so ∅ has to be an element. So unless one of a or b is ∅, X can't have ∅ as an element. Suppose a is ∅, so X = {∅, b}. Then the proper subsets are ∅, {∅}, and {b}. So for X to contain all proper subsets, {∅} must be in X, so b must be {∅}. Therefore, X would be {∅, {∅}}. The proper subsets are the first three. So X must contain ∅ (which it does), {∅} (which is an element), and {{∅}}. But X doesn't have {{∅}} as an element, only {∅} is there. Therefore, X doesn't contain all its proper subsets. Hence, even with two elements, it's not possible.

So, moving on, let's consider a general set X. Suppose X is non-empty and not {∅}. Let's assume X has at least one element. If X has an element, say 'a', then ∅ must be a subset, hence ∅ ∈ X. So X must contain ∅. If X has more than one element, say two elements: ∅ and a. Then the proper subsets would be ∅, {∅}, {a}, and maybe more depending on what 'a' is. Therefore, {∅} ∈ X. But X is {∅, a}, so either a = {∅} or not. If a = {∅}, then X = {∅, {∅}}, which we saw earlier doesn't work. If a is something else, then {a} is a subset, so {a} must be an element of X. Therefore, X must contain {a} as an element. The latter would require a to be a Quine atom, which in ZF set theory doesn't exist because of the axiom of regularity. So in standard ZF, there's no set a where a = {a}. Therefore, such an 'a' can't exist, so {a} can't be an element of X unless {a} is either ∅ or a, which isn't possible. Therefore, X can't satisfy the condition.

But in this case, ordinal 2 would need to contain all its proper subsets, but as we saw earlier, it doesn't. So ordinals beyond 1 don't satisfy the condition.

Another approach: Let's suppose X is a set that contains all its proper subsets. Then, since every element of X is a subset of X (because subsets are elements), X would be a transitive set. Transitive sets are such that every element is a subset. But here, the condition is stronger: every proper subset is an element.

Wait, if X is transitive, then elements of X are subsets of X. But here, we have that all proper subsets are elements. So X is transitive, and moreover, every subset of X is either X itself or an element of X. This seems similar to the concept of a quasicrystalline or something else, but maybe not.
